projectName: FINAL EVALUATION OF THE UNDP/GEF PROJECT EGY/99/G35 - Introduction of Vehicle Electric Bus Technology and Hybrid-Electric Bus Technology in Egypt - Phase 1a
Introduction of Viable Electric and Hybrid-Electric Bus Technology in Egypt
projectDetail: The project involved the introduction of electric and hybrid-electric bus technology in Egypt, specifically focusing on reducing urban air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. The project aimed to test 24 electric buses in historic sites and downtown routes, with the goal of eventually transitioning to locally manufactured electric buses. The project faced delays and challenges, but provided valuable insights into the operation and maintenance of electric buses in Egypt. The evaluation recommended exploring alternative financing options for future phases and expanding the use of electric buses to other historic sites and downtown areas.

The project aimed to introduce viable electric, hybrid-electric, and eventually fuel cell technology for buses in Egypt. It involved testing 24 electric buses in historic sites, training transportation managers, and developing plans for local manufacturing of electric drive systems. The initial phase (Phase 1a) tested two buses, with plans for a larger Phase 1b and Phase 2. However, due to funding issues, only Phase 1a was completed. The project faced delays and challenges but provided valuable insights for future phases. Recommendations include exploring alternative financing, implementing a concession model for bus operation, and expanding electric bus usage in major cities like Cairo.

The project is an evaluation of the UNDP/GEF project in Egypt focused on clean buses technology. The evaluation aims to assess project results and impacts, provide recommendations for sustainability and extension of services, extract lessons learned for future projects, and develop further project proposals. The final evaluation report will include an executive summary, introduction, key findings, recommendations, lessons learned, and annexes. The evaluation will be conducted by an independent international expert with qualifications in climate change, project evaluation, and familiarity with GEF rules. The methodology will include documentation review, interviews, field visits, and data analysis. The evaluation will address global environment objectives, project achievements, and GEF project review criteria. The scope of evaluation includes implementation approach, country ownership, stakeholder participation, sustainability, replication approach, financial planning, cost-effectiveness, and monitoring and evaluation. The evaluation report will adhere to GEF guidelines and include detailed analysis of project components.

[Project Name] CC MSP: Electric Buses
[Location] Egypt
[Year] 2010
[Description] Phase 1 involved trials with 2 and 22 electric buses in sub-phases 1a and 1b. Unexpected issues arose, leading to lessons learned in adjusting specifications for the Egyptian environment. Collaboration with industry associations and stakeholder participation were key. Financing for follow-up phases may come from Egyptian sources. Concession model proposed for operation of electric buses at historic sites. Challenges included technical problems, negotiations, and customs issues.
executingAgency: The executing agency for the project is the Social Fund for Development in Egypt.
status: Phase 1a of the project is completed, but Phase 1b and Phase 2 have not been started.
theme:
- Introduction of electric and hybrid-electric bus technology

contribution:
1. Testing and monitoring the operation of two electric buses in Phase 1a.
2. Training local technical staff on the operation and maintenance of electric buses.
3. Conducting an environmental and socio-economic impact analysis in 2003.
4. Formulating a proposal for Phase 1b to test 22 more buses.
5. Providing insights into the acquisition, operation, and maintenance of electric buses.
6. Transferring ownership of the buses to the Supreme Council of Antiquities.
7. Signing maintenance contracts for the buses with a consortium.
8. Raising interest among transport officials, government agencies, and private sector stakeholders.
9. Identifying the need for follow-up phases and potential financing options.
10. Presenting recommendations for future phases and expansion of electric bus technology in .
